title: More than 50 schools shut as snow causes disruption
text:
More than 50 schools shut as snow causes disruption
Schools across mid and west Wales have shut as snow and ice cause disruption.
The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning, and some areas could see up to 10cm of snow, particularly on higher ground, with a wider risk of icy surfaces making travel hazardous.
More than 30 schools have shut in Pembrokeshire, seven in Ceredigion and 14 in Carmarthenshire.
The National Grid said hundreds of properties in Pembrokeshire, Ceredigion and Carmarthenshire were without power.
Drivers and pedestrians are being urged to check conditions before travelling and be prepared for forecasts to change through the day.
Dyfed-Powys Police have reported the road from Templeton to Tavernspite is shut, and poor driving conditions on the A40 St Clears to Haverfordwest.
The B4329, Preseli Road, between Tafarn-y-bwlch and New Inn is impassable and remains closed.
The yellow snow and ice warning covers:
Carmarthenshire
Ceredigion
Pembrokeshire
Swansea
School closures
People have been told to keep updated on council website for school closure updates.
Driving in the snow
Councillor Shon Rees told BBC Radio Wales that parts of Pembrokeshire are experiencing "very very deep snow" with some areas seeing up to 10 inches.
He said the snow has persisted this morning and that driving conditions across the north of the county remain "very difficult".
Snow ploughs have been working through the area, and he said he had been helping a lorry free that became stuck in the snow as efforts continue to keep key routes open.
Rees said schools and the local authorities are taking the conditions seriously, adding that he thought it was the right decision for them to close.
Drivers are advised to leave extra time to prepare their vehicles, and carry essentials such as warm clothing, food, water, a blanket, a torch and a phone charger in case of delays.
Those heading out on foot are encouraged to use pavements along main roads, which are more likely to have been treated, to reduce the risk of slips and falls on icy surfaces.
Cyclists are also advised to stick to main routes for the same reason.
Households are being reminded to prepare for any short power cuts by keeping torches, spare batteries and a mobile pack ready.
The Met Office has warned that weather warnings can change quickly and recommends people keep up to date with the latest forecasts.
